posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked:
Hello, we are from Brazil’s 8882 team, we are designing an angled shooter for the First Championship, initially we think about angular him using PhotonVision, but as the distance from the speaker increases, it is difficult to see April tag.

So we had the idea of angular using swerve’s Odometry, so we made a calculation between the height of the Speaker and the distance of the robot from the zero point which would be the .getX() of the library, with this we calculate the arc tangent to get the launcher angle. But I presented several difficulties in implementing this within the code.

So I wanted to ask for help to do this, and also find out if it is possible. The Github repository is below.

https://github.com/oguiizim/Testes-Command-Based

Does your robot keep track of where it is on the field? What you could do is hard code the location of the speakers as constants, then get the distance and rotation between your robot and the speaker you’re aiming for. That’s how the targeting works on our robot and I can grab some example code to show how we’re doing it. Do note that I don’t know what programming language you’re using so I may or may not be able to help out in actually adapting it for you
These are the two functions we use to get the distance and rotation to the speaker from any position we are on the field

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: Yes we are using field orientation We are having a problem moving the shooter, we are not able to define the zero point to serve as a reference for the angulation, we are using the DutyCycleEncoder, and getting it to record that zero point is proving difficult. We use the Java language, if you can take a look at the code, it is an exemplary code to test the logic and then implement it in the code with swerve

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: I didn’t understand why you subtracted from the robot’s position minus the target, and in your equation you do this subtraction for the Y and the X, I didn’t understand this calculation, the calculation I had done used the Speaker’s height and the distance of the X axis

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Answer (1 of 7): For an angle, you need two lines, so I assume you mean the angle between the line defined by your two points and the coordinate axes?

So if you have the two points…

\quad \left( x_1, y_1 \right) \quad and \quad \left( x_2, y_2...

posts.name: Asher Olgeirson
posts.cooked: You can use a swerveDrivePoseEstimator combined with a photonPoseEstimator and create an angle function that uses your odometry to plug into an interpretation of successful as angles for a given pose.

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: We don’t want to use photon vision, because our processor is the limelight 3 processor, and to see the tags on the distance what we want, the latency is very big, so we don’t want to use câmera.
If I’m understanding you correctly, you know the distance from your robot to the target, and you’re trying to take that distance and get an angle?

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: Yes, I’m using the getPoseX of the YAGSL to discover the distance of the speaker, but I want to discover the angle of the shooter, and I don’t know how use this on the PID Controller, because e don’t know how set an zero point with the absolute encoder, I’m using the set offset, but it isn’t doing what I want

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Normally you don’t need to zero the absolute encoder or any encoder for each rotation especially since it’s used for pose estimation or filed orientation. You need to rotate a delta angle from wherever you happen to be. If your camera indicates you need to rotate +15 degrees then stop rotating when you are at the current orientation+15. Be aware of the various ways angles may be expressed from your gyro, say, +180 to -180 or 0 to 360 and continuous winding up (counting the rotations as 359+1 = 360) or resetting (359+1 = 0) Our complete code (it is potentially “overcoded” as we have had no time to refactor it and patched errors that we found):

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: I think u don understand me, I will use the getPoseX, to get the distance the robot of the the speaker, for example, the speaker will be on the point 0, and my robot Is in point 2meter, so I will calculate de angle of the shooter using the angle of right triangle, and the result is the angle of my shooter. But for do this, I need an 0 point on the shooter to be my reference point, bcs my shooter will be on 67deg from point zero, this is why I need to zero the encoder, or do anything to serve reference

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Here’s the rest of the related code for the angle - it’s essentially what has already been posted. It includes a solution to what you may be concerned about. There are (unfortunatley) two magic unary negative signs that make this work. You may have to adjust for your particular robot. My team’s shooter is located 180 degrees on the robot with the gyro located at 0 degrees on the robot. The Blue co-ordinates are 180 degrees mirrors of the Red. If your shooter isn’t located on your robot like my shooter is then you have to add (or subtract) your offset of the shooter to gyro.

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: This code is for get the robot angle, or get the shooter angle?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

estimatedPose

is the robot position.

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

redSpeakerCoords

is the speaker position.

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

gyro.getYaw()

is the gyro position.

posts.name: Krypton #9487
posts.cooked: To get the angle your shooter is at you can add a window to the shuffleboard and see the value. If you want to reset the problem to point 0 you can use the WPILIB guide here Or you can just add the value it is at at the 0 point you want, this is when you will get the absolute position on the shuffleboard + the value of your 0 point
